docs.lead_paragraph: Can free medical school help fix the American health care system? In this weekend’s opinion section, two physicians, Dr. Peter B. Bach and Dr. Robert Kocher, propose that it can.
docs.abstract: Fixing our health care system will be impossible without a larger pool of competent primary care doctors. One way to increase the number of primary care doctors is to make medical school free.
docs.snippet: Fixing our health care system will be impossible without a larger pool of competent primary care doctors. One way to increase the number of primary care doctors is to make medical school free.

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors were once overwhelmingly male and conservative. But today the politics of the medical profession are changing, as more doctors abandon independent practice for salaried jobs and more women are graduating from medical school, reports Gardiner Harris in the latest installment of his Doctors, Inc. series.
docs.abstract: The changing politics of the medical profession could have a profound effect on the healthcare debate.
docs.snippet: The changing politics of the medical profession could have a profound effect on the healthcare debate.

docs.lead_paragraph: As more doctors abandon practice ownership and take salaried hospital jobs, their priorities are changing.

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON - Soon enough, Democrats will have to identify new Medicare cuts they can support. But don't expect them to come this spring, not after the Medicare plan put forward by House Republicans became the centerpiece of the Democrats' strategy to recover from disastrous 2010 midterm elections. Last week's Democratic victory in a special House election in Buffalo ensured that.

headline.main: Seeing the Advantage In Delaying a Solution

docs.abstract: The Caucus column on decision by Democrats to hold back on offering new Medicare benefit cuts after Republican Rep Paul Ryan proposed cuts that they argue simply shifts costs from the government to the elderly; photo (M)
